text: Akt Regulates <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Synthesis Downstream of <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Kinase Activation during Necroptosis

Necroptosis is a regulated form of necrotic cell death that has been implicated in the pathogenesis of various diseases including intestinal inflammation and systemic inflammatory response syndrome ( SIRS ) .

In this work , we investigated the signaling mechanisms controlled by the necroptosis mediator <extra_id_0> receptor interacting protein-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) kinase .
We show that Akt kinase activity is critical for necroptosis in L929 cells and plays a key role in <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .
During necroptosis , Akt is activated in a <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> dependent fashion through its phosphorylation on Thr308 .
In L929 cells , this activation requires independent signaling inputs from both growth factors and <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Akt controls necroptosis through downstream targeting of mammalian Target of Rapamycin complex 1 ( mTORC1 ) .

Akt activity , mediated in part through mTORC1 , links <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to JNK activation and autocrine production of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

In other cell types , such as mouse lung fibroblasts and macrophages , Akt exhibited control over necroptosis - associated <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production without contributing to cell death .
Overall , our results provide new insights into the mechanism of necroptosis and the role of Akt kinase in both cell death and inflammatory regulation .
